results.title: The Running man (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Paul Michael Glaser, George Linder, Tim Zinnemann, Keith Barish Productions and Taft Entertainment
results.brief_description: The year is 2019. All that has survived of the 20th century is television. Television in a new and twisted fashion where the most powerful program on the air is a high-stakes, high-tech game show. “The Running man” is a deadly futuristic cat and mouse carnival in which contestants battle for the ultimate prize - survival! Based on the novel by Richard Backhman, this was rated one of the best action movies of the year.

results.title: The Runner
results.creator_credit: Amir Naderi, Alireza Zarrin and Inst for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults
results.brief_description: Buoyed by an extraordinary performance from Majid Nirumand, “Runner” is an evocative, memorable slice of life drama about an orphaned street kid who lives alone on a beached boat on the edge of the Persian Gulf and who, as the film progresses, attempts a variety of jobs to survive. The first post-revolution Iranian film to be released internationally, Naderi’s film is a beautifully photographed, deceptively simple film which is decidedly sophisticated in the ways it changes mood. Raw in parts, upbeat in others, Runner brilliantly uses striking images and sound to take you right into Amiro’s world. Winner of the International Critics Prize at the Melbourne Film Festival.

results.title: The Rumanian, Brancusi
results.creator_credit: Sean Hudson, Rodney Wilson, Arts Council of Great Britain and British Council
results.brief_description: This film explores the influence of Romanian sculptor Brancusi’s early childhood environment on his work and life. The director sees the film as “an ethnographic film about an artist”. Concentrates on the major works “Endless Column”, “The Gates of the Kiss” and “The Table of Silence”.

results.title: The Ruling class [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Medak, Jack Hawkins, Jules Buck and Keep Films
results.brief_description: Based on the stage play by Peter Barnes, this screen adaptation of “The Ruling class” (also written by Peter Barnes) remains true to the original farcical and darkly comic tale of British aristocracy. Combining the use of melodrama, musical and horror film genres, Peter Medak has created a totally bizarre visual feast of irony and parody of upper class England revolving around the rather unusual death of a British lord (Harry Andrews) who accidently hangs himself while in military uniform and a ballerina’s tutu. The Earl’s son, Jack Gurney (Peter O’Toole) becomes the 14th Earl of Gurney and finds himself named in the will as heir to the Gurney Estate. Only one problem - Jack is a paranoid schizophrenic who believes he is Jesus Christ. Jack’s disinherited relatives resolve to maintain their pride and their position as an upper class family and plot to have Jack committed to a mental institution and leave them as guardians to the Gurney Estate. However, Jack has to produce a family heir before any of this can take place. The lengths the family go to and the unexpected, hilarious and truly bizarre outcomes of their efforts, including Jack beginning to secretly think that he is Jack the Ripper and murdering one of the family members, add up to a most unusual and enjoyable cinematic experience consisting of narrative and vaudeville song-and-dance sequences, mixed in with a good measure of black comedy and contempt for the British class system. Cast also includes Arthur Lowe, Alastair Sim, Coral Browne, Michael Bryant, William Mervyn, Carolyn Seymour.

results.title: The Rules of the game = La Regle du jeu (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Claude Renoir and Nouvelle Edition Francaise
results.brief_description: On its initial release Renoir’s masterwork was greeted with contempt by critics, hostility by audiences and banned by the French government as “subversive” and “demoralising”. This restored version, put together under Renoir’s direction, makes available again one of the most acclaimed films ever made. A group of wealthy aristocratic and bourgeois Parisians holiday at their friend’s country chateau. There, as their amoral relationships turn alternately tragic or absurd, their lives and class are revealed as ultimately empty and decaying. Featuring some of the most beautifully constructed and edited sequences in film, Renoir’s direction - though seemingly understated - manages to convey the richness and complexity of a whole era and class: an era that World War II was to bring to an end. Restored by Jean Gaborit and Jacques Durand with approval and advice from Jean Renoir who dedicated it to the memory of Abdre Bazin. Music by Roger Desormieres; photographed by Sam Levin; wardrobe by Chanel.

results.title: The Rugrats movie (PC & MAC)
results.brief_description: This fun and interactive CD Rom is a great companion to “The Rugrats Movie”. Using the crazy antics of the Rugrats gang, it utilises the subject areas of English, music, maths and geography to guide children through different levels and activities. On successfully completing each section children can reach a ‘prize’. This could be either a game to play on screen, or a clip from the film. Certificates can be printed out after each section is completed. Suitable for children aged 6-12.

results.title: The Rugrats movie
results.brief_description: This is the first feature length adventure of the Rugrat babies, intrepid explorers and stars of Nickelodeon’s popular animated series created by Arlene Klasky and Gabor Csupo. When Tommy Pickles gets a new baby brother, Dil (short for Dylan), it’s the start of an amazing adventure for Tommy and his friends, Lil, Phil, Chucky and cousin Angelica. Tommy is not at all happy with the new addition to the family as he’s noisy and attention seeking. Sibling rivalry takes an unprecedented turn when Tommy decides to send his brother back where he came from- the hospital, to fix him up. While attempting to return little Dil to the hospital, the Rugrats (in the trusty Reptar Wagon) get lost in the forest that is the backyard and must successfully navigate some scary animal obstacles to make it home in one piece. Features the voices of E.G Daily, Christine Cavanaugh, Kath Soucie, Cheryl Case and Tara Charendoff. Cameos are provided by the voices of Iggy Pop, Whoopie Goldberg, David Spade, Lisa Loeb and Patti Smith.

results.title: The Royle family. Series 1
results.creator_credit: Mark Mylod, Glenn Wilhide and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: Written by Caroline Aherne (Denise Royle), Craig Cash (Dave) and Henry Normal, the plight of the Royle family - Denise, Barbara, Jim and Anthony - captured audiences across Britain with it’s distinct black humour and clever take on the kitchen sink dramas synonymous with directors such as Mike Leigh and Ken Loach. This tape contains the complete first series. EPISODE 1: Denise joins the workforce with a part time job in the bakery. Dad’s scrutinising a mysterious call on the itemized phone bill. EPISODE 2: The logistics of married life family dining is thrashed out and plans are well underway for Dave and Denise’s wedding. Everyone is eyeing the next door neighbours new purchase. EPISODE 3: Dinner commences between first and second generation family members. The women get a sneak peak of Denise’s wedding dress. EPISODE 4: Dad’s celebrating a birthday, much to his chagrin. Everyone is willing to join in, Jim just wants to go to the pub. EPISODE 5: There’s trouble in paradise as Denise and Dave bicker over Dave’s alleged flirtations. EPISODE 6: Wedding day arrives. Cast includes Caroline Aherne, Sue Johnston, Ricky Tomlinson, Ralf Little and Craig Cash.
